entry.title: Introduction to FinOps for Project and Program Managers
entry.content:
Introduction to FinOps for Project and Program Managers

(Understanding cost accountability in SAP cloud programmes)

Why FinOps Matters to Project and Program Managers

If you manage SAP projects or large transformation programmes, you will already recognise how significantly the cloud has altered the delivery landscape. Environments can now be provisioned quickly, capacity can be scaled with relative ease, and new services can be activated faster than in traditional on-premise models. This flexibility has undoubtedly improved speed and responsiveness, but it has also introduced a new dimension of financial complexity.

 

What is often less visible in the early stages of cloud adoption is how these technical choices translate into variable and sometimes unpredictable cost patterns. Consumption is no longer tied to fixed infrastructure sizing. Instead, spending fluctuates with usage, behaviour, and architectural choices. The financial impact is fully understood when bills are reviewed or budget thresholds are approached.

In one of the accounts I supported, the customer delivery and business teams initially struggled to grasp what FinOps really meant in practical terms. The focus remained firmly on technical readiness and go-live milestones, while cloud cost accountability was seen as something to address later. It only became a concern when increased consumption began affecting budget forecasts and triggering internal escalations. That experience reinforced for me that FinOps cannot be introduced as an afterthought ‚Äî it needs to be positioned early as part of programme governance, not merely as a financial control mechanism.

This is where FinOps becomes relevant to project and programme leadership.

 

What FinOps Is ‚Äì In Practical Terms

FinOps is the discipline of integrating financial awareness and accountability into cloud consumption decisions. In practical terms, it encourages collaboration among technology teams, finance functions, and business stakeholders to align cost considerations with performance, scope, and delivery timelines.

For project and programme managers, this does not mean becoming financial analysts or taking over cost control responsibilities. Instead, it involves understanding how delivery decisions influence cloud spending and ensuring that governance forums provide visibility into those implications.

 

FinOps helps project leaders ask practical questions such as:

  • Do we understand how our cloud environments are consuming resources?
  • Are the cost implications of design choices clearly communicated?
  • Is there clarity on who monitors and responds to cost trends?

 

Seen this way, FinOps becomes less about accounting and more about informed governance.

 

Where Project and Program Managers Fit In

It is essential to be clear that FinOps is not formally defined within SAP delivery methodologies as a direct responsibility of the Project or Program Manager. In most organisations, ownership typically resides with Cloud Centres of Excellence, platform governance functions, or financial oversight teams.

However, project and programme leaders occupy a unique position of influence. They shape delivery decisions, chair governance meetings, manage risks, and oversee the transition into steady-state operations. This puts them in a strong position to ensure cost accountability is not overlooked during execution.

In practice, this influence may take the form of:

  • Encouraging visibility of cloud usage and cost trends in governance forums
  • Ensuring cost implications are considered during scope or design changes
  • Supporting clarity on ownership for cost monitoring post go-live

These actions do not replace formal FinOps ownership; they strengthen alignment during the delivery lifecycle.

A Simple View of the FinOps Lifecycle

FinOps is commonly described through three broad stages:

  • Inform ‚Äì Gaining visibility into consumption and spend
  • Optimise ‚Äì Using that visibility to improve efficiency and decision-making
  • Operate ‚Äì Embedding monitoring and governance into ongoing operations

 

 

From a project and programme management perspective, this broadly translates into:

  • Ensuring cost visibility mechanisms exist during delivery
  • Making sure cost is part of decision-making discussions
  • Supporting the continuity of monitoring after go-live

The above aspects are not SAP-mandated interpretations, but a practical lens that helps clarify where FinOps intersects with delivery governance.

SAP BTP and Cost Visibility

Within SAP landscapes, SAP Business Technology Platform provides standard capabilities that support cost transparency and monitoring, including:

  • Cost and usage views at the global account level
  • Usage analytics at the subaccount level
  • Budget thresholds and alert mechanisms
  • Exportable usage data for reporting and analysis

Platform administrators or governance teams typically manage these tools. While project and programme managers are not expected to configure these capabilities, awareness of their existence helps them engage more effectively in governance discussions and ask the right questions around visibility and accountability.

 

Typical Risks When FinOps Is Overlooked

When cost accountability is not actively considered during delivery, programmes may encounter:

  • Unexpected cost escalation
  • Friction between IT and Finance over cost attribution
  • Delayed identification of inefficient consumption patterns
  • Reduced transparency during steering committee discussions

Recognising these risks early allows project leaders to introduce corrective governance measures before issues become financially disruptive.

 

What This Means for Project and Program Managers

For those leading SAP cloud initiatives, FinOps represents more of a mindset shift than a new operational burden. It encourages leaders to:

  • Integrate cost awareness into regular governance conversations
  • Avoid treating cloud spend as a secondary concern
  • Support structured handovers into steady-state operations

Even modest improvements in visibility and dialogue can lead to more informed decisions and better financial outcomes over time.

 

In Closing

FinOps introduces a structured approach to cost awareness that complements traditional project and programme management controls. While formal ownership of FinOps usually sits outside the PM function, project and programme leaders play an essential role in shaping how cost transparency is embedded during delivery.

Understanding the fundamentals of FinOps, knowing where it intersects with governance, and recognising when to engage the right stakeholders can significantly strengthen the financial resilience of SAP cloud programmes. For many delivery leaders, FinOps is less about controlling cost and more about making cost visible, understandable, and actionable at the right points in the project lifecycle.

 

References

SAP Help Portal ‚Äì SAP Business Technology Platform: Costs & Usage
Documentation covering monitoring, analysis, and governance of usage and cost within SAP BTP environments.

SAP Help Portal ‚Äì SAP Cloud Governance and Account Administration
Guidance on account structures, entitlement management, and governance responsibilities supporting cost visibility and financial control.

entry.title: Re: SAP Data Services Job "Hangs" Occasionally. Requires...
entry.content:
One possible workaround is to set the "Job History Cleanup Period" parameter; please see KBA 2776673 for details. Please note that this will impact all jobs. So, if the job is scheduled to run every 30 minutes and no other job runs for more than 30 minutes, you may set the parameter to 1800 seconds.
Additionally, DS 4.2 already reached EoL by the end of 2024, please upgrade to DS 4.3 or 2025.

entry.title: Re: onCellDoubleClick and Slipstream Engine
entry.content:
Hi Cristin,

I'm no scripting expert by a long shot but based on the API documentation I experimented a bit and found something that may help.

Here is this one-liner script:

session.utils.alert(rowIndex + ' ' + columnName + ' ' + cellValue);
If you attach this to the onCellDoubleClick event of your GuiTableControl, then double-clicking a cell will tell you which row, column name and cell content you double-clicked.

entry.title: Mastering Access Policies in SAP Integration Suite: How to Secure Your Integration Artifacts
entry.content:
Introduction:

In SAP Cloud Integration, multiple developers often collaborate on the same tenant. Without proper controls, anyone with design access can modify, delete, or copy iFlows and other artifacts ‚Äî leading to accidental changes or security issues.

To address this, SAP introduced Access Policies ‚Äî a feature that provides fine-grained control that goes beyond role-based permissions ‚Äî helping you secure design-time artifacts, deployed artifacts, and even data processed at runtime.

 

 What Are Access Policies?

Access Policies in SAP Integration Suite define what actions users can perform on integration artifacts such as iFlows, value mappings, and scripts etc.

Access Policies allow administrators to define exactly what operations a user or role can perform on different levels of integration artifacts.

You can restrict access to:

  • Design-Time Artifacts: Control operations in the Design workspace, such as creating, uploading, editing, saving, deploying, or deleting iFlows. Even simulation of artifacts can be restricted.

  • Deployed Artifacts: Control actions under Monitor ‚Üí Manage Integration Content, such as restarting or undeploying artifacts, or changing the log level.

  • Data Stored and Processed at Runtime: Restrict access to data collected or created during the execution of integration flows ‚Äî such as message processing logs, attachments, or business payload data available when using Trace log level.

Access Policies: SAP Help Portal 

Why Access Policies Are Needed

  • To prevent accidental edits or deletions in production packages.
  • To enforce segregation of duties (Developer vs Reviewer vs Administrator).
  • To improve governance in large integration landscapes.
  • To comply with audit and compliance requirements.

How to Configure Access Policies

Step 1: Navigate to Access Policies

Go to the Integration Suite Monitoring Tab and select Access Policies under the Manage Security.

Click on the "Create" button and provide a name and description for the role.
Note the role name, as you will use this same name for the role attribute value in the BTP for the Custom Role.
Here I am giving the Role name as "Z_INC_MaterialManagement"

Step 2: Create References

Create the reference to which you want to apply the access policy.

Enter a name of your choice and a description.

Here we have two options for applying restrictions for the Artifacts:

  1. Package-Level Restriction:
    Protect all artifacts of a certain integration package. 
    If you create an artifact reference for a specific integration package, it automatically includes all artifact types.
    (Useful when an entire package needs to be protected)

  2. Artifact-Level Restriction:

    Restricts access to individual artifacts like iFlow, Message Maping, Value Mapping, Script.
    (Useful when only certain iFlows or objects need restricted access)

    In Addition to this we can restrict the user for Data Store, Variables, Message Queue, Business data at runtime.

    Select an artifact type from the list, then choose the attribute name or ID and enter the corresponding value and then click on create.
    Here, I am providing the package name, which will protect all the flows within it.

In my package, I have four artifacts (two iFlows, one message mapping, and one value mapping).

After applying the policies, when I try to copy, edit, delete, download or Configure any of the artifacts, an error occurs.

With this access policy creation, all users in the Integration Suite will be restricted from accessing this integration package.

Additionally, the user won't be able to undeploy, restart, or download content from 'Manage Integration' in Monitoring. The user will also not be able to access data stored and processed by the artifact at runtime, such as attachments, data stores, or variables in the monitor message processing.

Now we need to create a custom role in BTP and assign it to the user who requires edit access for the Protected Package.
Users with the assigned role will only be able to access the protected artifacts.

Create a Custom Role in BTP Cockpit

Now we are going to create a Custom role in the BTP Cockpit.
Open the BTP Cockpit and selct the subaccount.
click on the Roles under the security Tab and search for the CustomRoleTemplate.

Now click on 'Create Role,' and a popup will open. Enter the role name and description, then click Next.


Keep the source as static, provide the value (the same value given in Step 1 while creating the access policy in Integration Suite Monitoring), and then click Enter.
Click Next, then Next again, and finally click Finish.

Go to the Role Collection and click on the Create button. A popup will open; provide the name and description, then click Create.

search and open the created Role collection and click on the edit

Click on the Role Name tab, search for the custom role you created, add the role, and then click Save

Now, we need to assign this role to the Integration Suite user to whom we want to grant access to edit the protected Integration Package/Integration Artifacts.

Go to Users, select the user to whom you want to grant access, and click on Assign Role Collection.

Search for the created role collection, select it, and assign the role collection.

 

With this, we have successfully created the role and assigned it to the user.
As a result, the assigned user will be able to access the protected integration package/artifacts, while other users will receive an access error.

Go to the Integration Suite Design tab and try to access the protected artifact. If the assigned user is able to edit the flow while other users receive an error, it means the applied access policy is working correctly.

 

Tips & Best Practices

  • Always test new policies in a test tenant first.
  • Use proper and consistent naming conventions to organize and manage Access Policies effectively
  • Regularly review access logs for compliance.

 

Monitoring and Validation

After setting up Access Policies:

  • Try editing or simulating an iFlow with restricted permissions ‚Äî it should be blocked.
  • Try accessing runtime data like trace logs ‚Äî restricted users should get ‚ÄúAccess Denied.‚Äù

This helps verify that your policies are correctly configured.

 

Conclusion

Access Policies in SAP Integration Suite empower administrators to control access across the entire lifecycle of an integration artifact ‚Äî from design, to deployment, to runtime.

By implementing them effectively, you can strengthen governance, reduce risks, and ensure your integration landscape remains secure and compliant.

entry.title: Driving Real-Time Pricing Digital Commerce: SAP Commerce with SAP CPS and S/4HANA
entry.content:
Introduction

Businesses demands delivering consistent pricing throughout the customer journey is key to modern digital commerce. By seamlessly connecting SAP Commerce with SAP Commerce Pricing Service (CPS) and deep-linking live S/4HANA business data delivers a modern, scalable solution for omnichannel pricing. Organizations can achieve real-time price calculation with full transparency for every product and transaction step. This blog demystifies the architecture, showcases the end-to-end solution, and explores technical best practices that make this integration foundational to digital commerce success.

Solution Overview

Our integrated solution enables:

  • The integration between SAP Commerce and SAP CPS enables real-time pricing functionality throughout the digital commerce experience.

  • Real-time context-aware price fetching for the Product Listing Page (PLP) and Product Detail Page (PDP) for all product types.

  • Dynamic context-aware cart price simulation and final price calculation during checkout.

  • Configuration-driven mapping of pricing conditions: total price, subtotal, base price, tax, and promotions.

  • SAP CPS acts as the orchestrator for pricing logic and maintains synchronization with SAP S/4HANA's pricing data for end-to-end Enterprise-grade consistency.

System Architecture

 

Key Components:

  • SAP Commerce Cloud: Handles storefront logic, triggers pricing requests, manages cart/checkout, and exposes APIs (OCC).

  • SAP Commerce Pricing Service (CPS): Microservice or cloud-based component responsible for price calculation, orchestration, and condition mapping.

  • SAP S/4HANA: System of record for product master data, pricing procedures, condition records, promotions, and taxes.

Process Flow:

  1. User action (PLP/PDP/cart/checkout) triggers a pricing request in Commerce.

  2. Commerce generates a context-rich pricing API call (including product, customer, sales org, and relevant parameters) to CPS.

  3. CPS retrieves or calculates prices, using mapping logic to apply configured condition types: base, subtotal, total, tax, promotion.

  4. If required, CPS makes a synchronous call to S/4HANA‚Äôs pricing engine, drawing on master data and up-to-date pricing procedures.

  5. CPS aggregates the response, applies additional logic (e.g., for promotions), and returns structured pricing details to Commerce.

  6. Commerce returns the final price breakdown to the storefront (via OCC APIs) for user display.

  7. For cart simulation or checkout, a fresh real-time price calculation is performed to ensure all conditions and promotions are current.

How It Works

Custom Configuration are injected at the base store level to select the relevant Pricing conditions for the relevant prices and also to enable the PLP, PDP prices retrieval from CPS.

Also the below classes have been extended to achieve the functionality.

PLP: 

public class CustomSearchResponseResultsPopulator<FACET_SEARCH_CONFIG_TYPE, INDEXED_TYPE_TYPE, INDEXED_PROPERTY_TYPE, INDEXED_TYPE_SORT_TYPE, ITEM> extends SearchResponseResultsPopulator

    @Override
    protected List<SearchResultValueData> buildResults(final SearchResult searchResult, final SearchQuery searchQuery)
    {
        final List<SearchResultValueData> result = super.buildResults(searchResult, searchQuery);

        String sort = searchQuery.getNamedSort();
        if(CollectionUtils.isNotEmpty(result)
                && ( StringUtils.isBlank(sort) || (StringUtils.isNotBlank(sort) && !SORT_KEY_IN.equalsIgnoreCase(sort))))
        {
            BaseStoreModel baseStore = baseStoreService.getCurrentBaseStore();
            if (Objects.nonNull(baseStore) && Objects.nonNull(baseStore.getSAPConfiguration()) && Boolean.TRUE.equals(baseStore.getSAPConfiguration().getPlpCPSPricing()))
            {
                customCPSPricingService.plpSimulatePricing(result, baseStore);
            }
        }

        return result;
    }

PDP:

public class CustomProductDiscountedPricePopulator<SOURCE extends ProductModel, TARGET extends ProductData>
        extends AbstractDiscountPopulator<SOURCE, TARGET> {

    @Override
    public void populate(SOURCE source, TARGET target) throws ConversionException
    {
        
        //CPS Synchronous Pricing.
        BaseStoreModel baseStore = baseStoreService.getCurrentBaseStore();
        if (Objects.nonNull(baseStore) && Objects.nonNull(baseStore.getSAPConfiguration()) && Boolean.TRUE.equals(baseStore.getSAPConfiguration().getPdpCPSPricing()))
        {
            customCPSPricingService.productSimulatePricing(target, source, baseStore);
        }
    }
}

CPS Pricing Service and Build the Pricing Document Input

public class CustomCPSPricingServiceImpl{

    public void cpsSimulateOrder(AbstractOrderModel cart, BaseStoreModel baseStore)
    {
        resetCartPrices(cart);
        try {
            if (CollectionUtils.isNotEmpty(cart.getEntries())) {
                LOG.info("cpsSimulateOrder");
                final PricingDocumentInput pricingDocumentInput = customPricingDocumentInputPopulator.populate(cart);

                // Prepare Pricing Result
                final PricingDocumentResult pricingDocumentResult = charonPricingFacade.createPricingDocument(pricingDocumentInput);

                List<PricingItemResult> pricingItemResultItems = pricingDocumentResult.getItems();

                for (AbstractOrderEntryModel entryModel : cart.getEntries()) {
                    List<String> itemIds = getEntriesItemIds(entryModel, pricingDocumentInput);
                    List<PricingItemResult> pricingItemResults = pricingItemResultItems.stream().filter(pricingItemResultItem -> itemIds.contains(pricingItemResultItem.getItemId()))
                            .collect(Collectors.toList());
                    if (CollectionUtils.isNotEmpty(pricingItemResults)) {
                        populateEntryBasePrice(entryModel, pricingItemResults, baseStore);
                        populateEntryBaseDiscount(entryModel, pricingItemResults, baseStore);
                        populateEntryEcoTax(entryModel, pricingItemResults, baseStore);
                        populateEntryDealerMargin(entryModel, pricingItemResults, baseStore);
                        populateEntryTotalPrice(entryModel, pricingItemResults, baseStore);

                        entryModel.setCalculated(true);
                        modelService.save(entryModel);
                    }
                }
                populateCartSubTotalPrice(cart, pricingDocumentResult, baseStore);
                populateCartEcoTax(cart, pricingDocumentResult, baseStore);
                populateCartDealerMargin(cart, pricingDocumentResult, baseStore);
                populateCartDiscount(cart, pricingDocumentResult, baseStore);
                populateCartTax(cart, pricingDocumentResult, baseStore);
                populateCartTotalPrice(cart, pricingDocumentResult, baseStore);

                cart.setCalculated(true);
                cart.setErrorDuringSimulation(false);
            }
        } catch (ConfigurationEngineException | PricingEngineException exp) {
            LOG.error(String.format("CPS Order Simulation failed due to %s", exp.getMessage()));
            cart.setErrorDuringSimulation(true);
        }
        modelService.save(cart);
    }


    public void productSimulatePricing(ProductData productData, ProductModel productModel, BaseStoreModel baseStore)
    {
        LOG.info("productSimulatePricing");
        if(Objects.nonNull(productModel))
        {
            PricingDocumentResult pricingDocumentResult = null;
            productData.setPricingError(Boolean.FALSE);
            try
            {
                // Prepare Pricing Input
                final PricingDocumentInput pricingDocumentInput = customProductPricingDocInputPopulator.populate(productModel);
                pricingDocumentResult= charonPricingFacade.createPricingDocument(pricingDocumentInput);

            } catch (PricingEngineException e)  {
                LOG.error("Error while populating Product PDP price from CPS!", e);
                productData.setPricingError(Boolean.TRUE);
            }
            populateProductSubTotalPrice(productData, pricingDocumentResult, baseStore);
            populateProductDiscountLabel(productData, pricingDocumentResult, baseStore);
            populateProductTotalPrice(productData, pricingDocumentResult, baseStore);
        }
    }


    public void plpSimulatePricing(List<SearchResultValueData> result, BaseStoreModel baseStore)
    {
        LOG.info("plpSimulatePricing");
        resetePLPPrices(result);
        try
        {
            // Prepare Pricing Input
            final PricingDocumentInput pricingDocumentInput = customPLPPricingDocInputPopulator.populate(result);
            PricingDocumentResult pricingDocumentResult= charonPricingFacade.createPricingDocument(pricingDocumentInput);

            for (PricingItemResult pricingItemResult : pricingDocumentResult.getItems())
            {
                SearchResultValueData data = result.get(Integer.valueOf(pricingItemResult.getItemId()));

                populatePLPSubTotalPrice(data, pricingItemResult, baseStore);
                populatePLPDiscountLabel(data, pricingItemResult, baseStore);
                populatePLPTotalPrice(data, pricingItemResult, baseStore);
            }

        } catch (PricingEngineException e)  {
            LOG.error("Error while populating PLP price from CPS!", e);
            result.forEach(data->data.getValues().put("pricingError",Boolean.TRUE));
        }
    }

}
public class CustomPLPPricingDocumentInputPopulator extends AbstractPricingDocumentInputPopulator
{
    public PricingDocumentInput populate(List<SearchResultValueData> result)
    {
        PricingDocumentInput target = new PricingDocumentInput();
        fillCoreAttributes(target);
        fillPricingItemsInput(result, target);
        return target;
    }

    protected void fillPricingItemsInput(List<SearchResultValueData> result, final PricingDocumentInput target)
    {
        target.setItems(new ArrayList<>());

        int i=0;
        for(SearchResultValueData data:result)
        {
            populateAsNormalItem(i++, data, target);
        }
    }

    protected void populateAsNormalItem(Integer i, SearchResultValueData data, final PricingDocumentInput target)
    {
        String code = (String) data.getValues().get("code");

        CPSQuantity cpsQuantity = new CPSQuantity();
        cpsQuantity.setUnit("PCE");
        cpsQuantity.setValue(1d);

        CPSItem source = new CPSItem();
        source.setId(i.toString());
        source.setQuantity(cpsQuantity);
        source.setKey(code);
        source.setType(SapproductconfigruntimecpsConstants.ITEM_TYPE_MARA);
        source.setVariantConditions(new ArrayList<>());

        fillPricingItemInput(source, target.getItems(), null);
    }


    protected void fillPricingItemInput(final CPSItem item, final List<PricingItemInput> target, final ConfigurationRetrievalOptions context)
    {
       PricingItemInput pricingItemInput = pricingItemInputConverter.convertWithContext(item, context);
        target.add(pricingItemInput);
    }

}
public class CustomProductPricingDocumentInputPopulator extends AbstractPricingDocumentInputPopulator
{
    public PricingDocumentInput populate(final ProductModel product) {
        PricingDocumentInput target = new PricingDocumentInput();
        fillCoreAttributes(target);
        fillPricingItemsInput(product, target);
        return target;
    }

    protected void fillPricingItemsInput(final ProductModel product, final PricingDocumentInput target) {
        target.setItems(new ArrayList<>());
        populateAsNormalItem(product, target);
    }

    protected void populateAsNormalItem(ProductModel product, final PricingDocumentInput target) {

        CPSQuantity cpsQuantity = new CPSQuantity();
        cpsQuantity.setUnit("PCE");
        cpsQuantity.setValue(1d);

        CPSItem source = new CPSItem();
        source.setId("1");
        source.setQuantity(cpsQuantity);
        source.setKey(product.getCode());
        source.setType(SapproductconfigruntimecpsConstants.ITEM_TYPE_MARA);
        source.setVariantConditions(new ArrayList<>());

        fillPricingItemInput(source, target.getItems(), null);
    }


    protected void fillPricingItemInput(final CPSItem item, final List<PricingItemInput> target,
          final ConfigurationRetrievalOptions context)
    {
       PricingItemInput pricingItemInput = pricingItemInputConverter.convertWithContext(item, context);
        target.add(pricingItemInput);
    }

}

 

1. Real-Time Price Retrieval

Each time a customer browses a product (PLP/PDP), the Commerce storefront triggers a call to the CPS service. The request includes product ID, customer context, and essential pricing parameters.

  • For every product displayed, Commerce invokes CPS, passing the product, customer details, and required pricing condition context.

  • CPS returns itemized pricing: base price, taxes, promotions, mapped from condition types configured in S/4HANA.

2. Pricing Condition Mapping

SAP CPS is configured to map S/4HANA pricing condition types to required display elements (base price, subtotal, total, tax, promotion). For example, PR00 for base price, MWST for tax, or ZPR0 for promotions.

  • Mapping between SAP S/4HANA pricing conditions (e.g., PR00 for base price, MWST for tax, ZPR0 for promotions) and Commerce pricing roles is handled in CPS.

  • Price response structure typically includes:

    • Base Price: Sourced via condition type (e.g., PR00)

    • Subtotal: Sum prior to tax/promotion (may use calculated subtotal condition)

    • Tax: Fed from tax condition (e.g., MWST)

    • Promotion/Discount: Special condition types as assigned in S/4HANA pricing procedures

  • This mapping is managed in CPS configuration, allowing for rapid change without code updates in Commerce.

3. Cart Simulation and Checkout

When items are added to the cart or quantities changed, Commerce requests a fresh price simulation from CPS, capturing up-to-date promotions and calculating taxes dynamically. During checkout, the system fetches real-time prices from S/4HANA, ensuring all figures are final and compliant.

  • Each cart event (add/remove/update item) triggers a re-simulation request to CPS.

  • CPS may aggregate line-item responses, apply global/cart-level promotions, and respect tax logic.

  • At checkout, a final real-time price retrieval ensures promotions and pricing are current, before order submission.

4. S/4HANA Synchronization

CPS either fetches current prices from S/4HANA (via synchronous API) or synchronizes relevant condition master data. This guarantees every price shown reflects S/4HANA‚Äôs latest logic, promoting transparency and auditability.

  • Master data and pricing condition records are synchronized (batch or real-time) via CPI to keep price calculations accurate.

  • SAP CPS either performs stateless pricing (reading reference data from S/4HANA) or document pricing (mirroring S/4HANA calculation logic in simulated documents).

  • Consistency is maintained by aligning product, customer, and pricing data between Commerce, CPS, and S/4HANA to prevent discrepancies and ensure synchronized updates.

Configuration Highlights

  • Flexible Condition Assignment: Pricing condition codes can be mapped per channel, market, or customer segment in CPS configuration.

  • Promotion Engine Integration: Cart-level and item-level discounts are handled through mapped pricing condition types, enabling commerce-driven promotion scenarios to flow through SAP‚Äôs pricing stack.

  • Extensibility: The entire architecture supports plug-and-play enhancements, such as new tax rules or advanced promotion logic, without deep code changes.

Business Impact

  • Customer Trust: Shoppers see consistent, reliable pricing from product discovery to checkout.

  • Operational Agility: Pricing changes in S/4HANA take effect instantly in Commerce.

  • Compliance: All tax and price breakdowns are traceable to ERP rules, simplifying audits.

Key Benefits

  • Unified, accurate pricing across all customer touchpoints.

  • Seamless integration for complex pricing scenarios, including promotions, tiered pricing, and taxes.

  • Real-time pricing reflection driven by master data consistency and robust API orchestration.

  • Extensible architecture supporting further enhancements and new pricing models.

‚Äã

Summary

This architecture achieves the grail of omnichannel commerce: unified, authoritative, and real-time pricing for every product and transaction. The combination of SAP Commerce, CPS, and S/4HANA provides a scalable foundation for global businesses requiring flexibility, transparency, and operational excellence. Integrating SAP Commerce Cloud with SAP CPS and S/4HANA pricing transforms the digital commerce experience. Enterprises gain agility, compliance, and a seamless customer journey, all backed by the power of modern SAP integration best practices.‚Äã

entry.title: Re: Billing completed but still showing in VA05 Open orders
entry.content:
Hi @JiteshNair 

What i understand from your explanation, this is a classic SAP SD inconsistency problem. Sales orders that are fully billed but still appear in VA05 (List of Sales Orders) as ‚Äúopen,‚Äù and they don‚Äôt show up in VBUP (Sales Document: Item Status). The reason can be due to following as mentioned below. VA05 doesn‚Äôt check billing completion directly. It looks at delivery/billing status fields in VBUK (Sales Document Header Status) and VBUP (Item Status). If those status fields aren‚Äôt updated correctly, the order still appears as ‚Äúopen.‚Äù Missing VBUP entries: If the sales order items aren‚Äôt in VBUP, the system can‚Äôt mark them as ‚Äúcompleted.‚Äù This usually points to: Data inconsistency (update failure during delivery/billing). Customization/user exits interfering with status updates. Technical issues like incomplete updates in the database. Billing completion vs. order completion: Even if billing is done, the order may not be marked as ‚Äúcompleted‚Äù if: Delivery status isn‚Äôt set to ‚Äúcompleted.‚Äù Billing status isn‚Äôt updated in VBUK/VBUP. The ‚Äúcompletion rule‚Äù in the item category isn‚Äôt set properly. Check VBUK table Run SE16N for your sales order numbers in VBUK. Look at fields: CMGST (Overall processing status) CMPSP (Overall delivery status) CMPSB (Overall billing status) If these aren‚Äôt set to ‚ÄúC‚Äù (Completed), VA05 will still show them as open. Check item category completion rule In customizing (VOV7), verify the completion rule for the item category. If it‚Äôs not set to mark the item as complete after billing, VA05 will keep showing it. Run report RVKRED77 / SDVBUK/VBUP repair SAP provides consistency check programs: RVKRED77 or SDVBUK/VBUP repair reports can rebuild missing VBUP entries and correct status inconsistencies. Hope you can catchup the issue and fix

entry.title: Re: Tech-user got locked - how to unlock it
entry.content:
Dear customer,

In order to check the lock status (and unlock) the Technical Communication User, you may refer to the following steps:

Prerequisite: Any Super Administrator or User Administrator can perform these steps.

  1. Open the  Technical Communication Users application
  2. Locate the Technical Communication User (S-user ID) in the list of users 
  3. If locked, the user will display a padlock in the Active for Data Transfer column
  4. Click anywhere in that user's row
  5. Click Unlock

Also check the detailed information in KBA 2392726 - How to unlock a Technical Communication User ID (e.g. "401" errors) - SAP for Me.

Hope this helps.

Thanks and regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: SAP RPT-1: Ready-to-Use AI for Structured Data
entry.content:
Hi @dirkpelz  

Thank you for your comment.

Yes, seeing "null" as a confidence level is not very convincing. Especially when we have (as you called it) high-stake decisions where you need to have a confidence value to decide whether you trust the prediction or not.

For this demo I manually cross-checked the given predictions against my data set (csv file) to see if the results made sense. But I must admit that this is not the right way to validate a model, and it doesn‚Äôt scale when working with larger datasets. For the next API Version, I would love to see the confidence level in the output. 

One approach for temporary workaround which came to my mind was "stability voting" - Sending the same data to RPT multiple times but with different ordering of the context rows. Ideally the predicted results should not change. That would give at least an indication if the model is reliable.

But as already mentioned, having the confidence level per predicted field for decision making would be great!

entry.title: Re: Integrate SAP AFC with SAP Fiori App (on-premise)
entry.content:
Hi, the question is not clear to me. But let me try to answer.

SAP AFC Fiori¬¥s are running at SAP BTP only. There you create a template and connect it via a communication system with your backend. You can select then any Fiori app based task model and add it as task at you template.

How to define task models at your backend is described here https://help.sap.com/docs/advanced-financial-closing/local-settings/sap-fiori-applications-in-advanced-financial-closing in the local settings guide.

For sure the Fiori Apps of SAP S/4HANA are running at SAP S/4HANA and SAP AFC only "calls" them to open it up.

Maybe you can clarify / more details in case it does not answer your question.

Regards

Thomas

entry.title: The AI Associate: The AI Era Sales Playbook
entry.content:
The traditional Discovery to Closure cycle is fading. Legacy CRM, even with UI polish, simply cannot keep pace with modern data volumes, self-educated buyers, and multi-channel engagement. Sellers are buried under admin, compliance, and hygiene rituals that belong to automation.

The result is simple. Tactics that once worked now run on fumes.

What defines future selling is velocity, clarity, autonomy, and low touch, not more fields to fill.

This frees sales and account executives to do the only things humans should be doing:
building relationships, earning trust, reading nuance, and applying instinct.

The future will not be shaped by recreating old CRM screens. It will be defined by redesigning the act of selling itself, with AI sitting at the deal table, not watching from the sidelines.

Why chase yesterday‚Äôs like-for-like rebuilds when the whole model can be smarter, leaner, and infinitely cleaner?

II. Reimagining the Ecosystem

The future is not about copying old CRM features. It is about designing an extensible, intelligent ecosystem where the AI Associate becomes the connective tissue.

This new architecture unifies specialist platforms such as Emarsys, Gainsight, Icertis, CPQ, and Commerce Cloud alongside Joule or Agentic AI, with SAP Sales Cloud v2 as the experience anchor.

The result:
An environment built for Intelligent Orchestration, not static workflows.

Emarsys strengthens the very top of the funnel, creating the right demand, signals, and engagement readiness before sales even enters the flow.
Commerce Cloud supports digital partner and indirect sales motions, reinforcing your reference to digital channels for the partner ecosystem.

III. The Future-State Process: Co-Ownership and Collaboration

It is a two-pronged model.

Selling becomes non-linear, a shared motion between human and AI at the core of the deal cycle.

In parallel, the partner ecosystem and franchise force run their own digitally enabled B2B motions, with AI acting as the connective layer that surfaces the right partner, the right context, and the right data to enable scalable value.
Here, Commerce Cloud quietly powers the digital shelf and partner storefronts without stealing the spotlight.

Stage: Start - Sensing and Signal Capture

Emarsys fuels engagement signals and behavior patterns.
AI picks up intent, product usage, and sentiment cues across systems.

Stage: Qualification - Automated Opportunity Formulation

AI drafts the opportunity blueprint, maps stakeholders, and proposes the initial motion.
CPQ metadata and rulesets begin shaping what is realistically buildable, configurable, or priceable.
No manual entry. Zero friction.

Stage: Negotiation - Negotiation Intelligence

AI pulls insights from contracting (Icertis), customer sentiment (Gainsight), CPQ configurations, and deal history to guide the seller in real time.

Stage: Post-Close - Expansion Intelligence

AI monitors sentiment, adoption, renewal cues, and feeds signals back to the top of the funnel, keeping the flywheel alive.

Sales Associate Blueprint

Stage

AE ActionsAI Associate (Joule) ActionsSAP Cloud Apps
Demand & EngagementPrioritizes accounts, validates signalsPredicts segments, nudges early insights ‚Üí early instinctsEmarsys
Lead QualificationReviews opportunity blueprint, validates leadsScores leads, maps stakeholders, recommends next steps (Assistant ‚Üí Associate begins)Sales Cloud
DiscoveryCo-decides solution approach, builds trustHighlights use cases, surfaces opportunities, guides decisions (Shaping seller instincts)Sales Cloud
ConfigureAdjusts, approves configurationsSuggests bundles, validates CPQ rules, drafts proposals (Embedded, context-aware Associate)CPQ
Quote & ProposalReviews proposals, adds negotiation contextEnsures pricing accuracy, nudges next-step strategy (Associate driving outcomes)CPQ
Commit & CloseCloses deal, signs offPredicts win likelihood, suggests negotiation moves, closes loop with signals (Instincts fully activated; Full Associate)Sales Cloud, Commerce Cloud

IV. Conclusion ‚Äì Vision to Value

The future is straightforward.
The AI Associate drives the volume.
The human seller closes the value.

The sales team has clear instincts to act with confidence and lead with vision.

The forward looking Joule Associate stays Relevant, Reliable, and Responsible by keeping humans in the driver‚Äôs seat, always.

Humans define the mission (in command),
supervise the automation (on the loop),
and validate the critical decisions (in the loop).

Winning will not come from rebuilding legacy CRM experiences. It will come from embracing a new sales architecture where AI sits at the deal table as a colleague, not a tool.

 

 

                    

  

 

                          A L-2 View of the Agentic Layer Associating Sales Cloud V2

 

Think of this as a mindset nudge. Our customer conversations need to pivot toward what is emerging, not what is evaporating. The point is not to recreate old rituals. It is to guide them into a smarter, cleaner way of selling in the AI era.

Think of this as a mindset nudge. Our solution design approach  for modern sales playbook, while embarking on transformation Journey need to pivot towards what is emerging, not what is evaporating. The point is not to recreate old rituals. It is to guide them into a smarter, cleaner way of selling in the AI era.

entry.title: New Customer Influence Sessions for SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Hi all,

Since the launch of SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC), in February 2025, we have been overwhelmed with the level of customer interest and adoption. As we began the rollout, we have had several feedback programs with customers to help bring them live for the key use cases we seek to enable. We now want to scale this to a broader community of customers through SAP Influence.

We are writing this post to announce 2 things:

  1. We are renaming our existing Data & Analytics sessions to BDC Datasphere and BDC: SAP Analytics Cloud. This move has no impact on investment priorities or the delivery of existing ideas. We are making this change to reflect that these products are now part of SAP Business Data Cloud.
  2. We are bringing onboard new influence communities for BDC Catalog, BDC BW Modernization, BDC: SAP Databricks, BDC Administration, BDC Connect, BDC Intelligent Applications & Data Products.

The changes to existing communities and creation of new communities will happen in the next couple of days. There will also be some movement of ideas between session categories over the next couple of weeks as we implement this new setup. We will update this blog with a link to the new sessions directly after we launch them. We will also add SAP BDC to the central entry point for key influence sessions located here. 

The reason we decided to split SAP BDC into multiple influence sessions is to make it easy for individual users to follow the areas which interest them. Some of these areas are early in their product lifecycle, but they will gain momentum over time and influence will help with this progress. 

We will also use this opportunity to improve our community's responsiveness and communication across all SAP BDC products by reusing the processes that we used for SAP Analytics Cloud in the last couple of years. We cannot deliver all customer requests, but Influence Communities are really useful to understand customer pain points and help identify customers who can deliver feedback on upcoming features. We are always listening and watching.

The BDC session group with its influence communities mentioned above will be owned by the BDC enablement, evangelism and community team under Subha Ramachandran, in Product Management. The influence sessions will be actively managed in partnership with our Product Success teams. I had the privilege to work on the initial strategy and set up the community because of my work on the SAP Analytics Cloud Influence session, which I will continue into the future.

Thanks,
Richard

entry.title: Proactive Monitoring that Integrates Retail Operations in a Data-driven World
entry.content:
Imagine a global retailer preparing for the holiday season, a time when system stability is paramount. In previous years, unexpected disruptions caused delays and customer dissatisfaction. This year, things are different. By implementing proactive monitoring powered by AI and Collective Intelligence, the retailer identified early signals of potential issues weeks before peak demand. This story exemplifies how proactive monitoring transforms support from reactive firefighting to predictive prevention.

Why Proactive Monitoring Matters

Proactive monitoring reduces escalations, improves customer confidence, and optimizes operations. Instead of waiting for incidents to occur, we anticipate them, ensuring uninterrupted business continuity. For example, during the Holiday Season Readiness Program, proactive monitoring helped SAP support teams detect anomalies in critical systems, preventing potential outages for major e-commerce customers.

How It Works

The process begins with comprehensive data collection‚Äîtelemetry from cloud systems, business process data, and historical case patterns. AI-driven algorithms then analyze these inputs to recognize patterns and correlate events. When anomalies are detected, automated workflows trigger alerts and initiate Preventive Customer Risk Mitigation actions.

Breaking Data Silos

Success depends on breaking down data silos. Only by building a Collective Intelligence framework‚Äîwhere insights from global case data, configuration logs, and usage analytics converge‚Äîcan this model be scaled across the entire customer base. As data needs to be used collaboratively, data sharing enables an environment where information is accessible in a timely manner.

Benefits

Among the benefits of proactive monitoring, they can range from faster root cause analysis to reduced mean time to resolution. The first refers to the process of identification of causes and reasons for an issue taking place, and the latter concerns the measurement of how quickly a system responds to a failure once it is recognized. Both play a part in refining the customer experience through invisible, but automated support.

With the proactive monitoring strategy anchored in AI, retailers can turn their peak shopping seasons from difficult periods into opportunities for improving customer engagement and operational resilience. A continued adoption of AI-driven capabilities is what will enable smarter planning and sustainable data-driven growth. strategic AI adoption and thoughtful implementation will drive retail excellence in an increasingly digital and data-driven world.

A special thanks to SAP experts Bharath Ramamurthy, Vice President of Strategic Initiatives, Customer Support, and Kartikaye Gomber, AI Solution Architect, for their contributions to this article.

entry.title: To the Left, To the Left: Setting Businesses Up for Irreplaceable Success
entry.content:
Consider a scenario where a critical update is scheduled for a financial services customer ahead of a major fiscal event. Traditionally, risks would surface post-deployment, leading to costly escalations. That is where a shift to the left walks into the stage: as the testing and detection steps are moved earlier into the lifecycle, an eventual delay in release is avoided, as well as the increase in costs associated with fixings issues. In other words, shifting to left is like reserving the seat in the first rows for testing!

At first glance, it may appear that risks are put in the spotlight, much like nominees at an award show. However, in reality, this approach aims at reducing them. Early recognition of potential issues enables development teams to allocate more time to data cleansing and preparation, tasks that typically consume a significant part of their efforts. This proactive approach allows for more focus on generating valuable insights rather than dealing with escalations.

What Does Shift Left Mean?

Shift Left involves moving risk detection and mitigation earlier in the lifecycle. This approach reduces downstream support costs and enhances customer satisfaction. During the Holiday Season Readiness Program, Shift Left strategies ensured that preventative controls were in place well before peak transaction periods. These strategies included:

  • Implementing Preventive Customer Risk Mitigation workflows for early alerts and automated case creation
  • Integrating with Cloud ALM for lifecycle event monitoring
  • Defining governance models for clear ownership of risk mitigation

Predictive Intelligence

Predictive intelligence uses Collective Intelligence to aggregate insights from global case data and apply AI models for event-to-issue correlation. This enables proactive actions that prevent disruptions before they impact customers.

Breaking Data Silos for Scale

Scaling this model requires dismantling data silos. By pooling insights across teams and regions, we create a unified intelligence network capable of supporting our entire customer base efficiently. With reliable data through the software deployment process, customers can make well-informed decisions at all stages of their businesses, that could lead to better budget management likewise.

Impact

This method is aligned with SAP‚Äôs vision for an effortless customer experience. It reduces escalations and downtime while improving operational efficiency. By incorporating recurrent tests at every step of the development process, the system is continuously reviewed and adjusted as needed. Just as filming involves many behind-the-scenes teams, a shift to the left ensures that the backstage engines are aware and constantly prepared for the result that customers witness.

In conclusion, the Shift Left approach changes traditional development and deployment processes by proactively addressing risks and issues earlier in the lifecycle. When customers operate their businesses smoothly and stay well-prepared, we join forces to lay the foundation for lasting success and sustained trust.

A sincere thank you to SAP experts Bharath Ramamurthy, Vice President of Strategic Initiatives, Customer Support, and Kartikaye Gomber, AI Solution Architect, for their contributions to this article

entry.title: Delivering a 360¬∞ Customer View in SAP Sales Cloud V2 Using SAP CDP and Build Apps
entry.content:
Today‚Äôs sales operations extend far beyond traditional CRM data. To make accurate, timely decisions, sales teams need deeper customer intelligence such as behavioural indicators, marketing engagement metrics, transactional history, digital footprints, sentiment analysis, and segment classifications. SAP Customer Data Platform (CDP) integrates these diverse data points into a single, real-time unified profile.

This blog explains how to bring a full 360¬∞ Customer View into SAP Sales Cloud V2 using:

  • SAP CDP as the unified profile and interaction source
  • SAP Build Apps to build custom UI extensions
  • SAP Sales Cloud V2 mashup capabilities to embed the experience seamlessly

 

Why a 360¬∞ Customer View Matters for Sales Reps

Traditional CRM systems give sales reps only a basic snapshot of customer information, such as:

  • Account and contact details
  • Open opportunities
  • Logged activities and visits
  • Quotes and order history

While useful, this limited view often leaves sales reps without the full context they need. In today‚Äôs competitive environment, reps must understand how customers think, behave, and engage. This requires deeper insights, including:

  • Email engagement patterns (opens, clicks, conversions)
  • Website behaviour and product interest
  • Cross-channel interaction history
  • Purchase trends and loyalty behaviours
  • Segment membership and scoring
  • Predictive signals like propensity to buy or churn risk

 

SAP CDP transforms fragmented data into a unified, real-time Golden Profile. With SAP Build Apps extending Sales Cloud V2, this intelligence flows directly to sales users at the critical moment‚Äîwhen they‚Äôre engaging with customers and making key decisions.

High-Level Architecture

 

 

Implementation Steps

Step 1: Enable CDP API Access

SAP CDP exposes APIs for:

  • Profiles
  • Interactions
  • Orders
  • Calculated attributes

Configure OAuth client in CDP and note:

  • Base URL
  • Client ID
  • Client Secret

 

Step 2: Configure BTP Destination

In SAP BTP:

Name: CDP

Type: HTTP

Proxy Type: Internet

URL: https://<tenant>. gigya.com

This is consumed by SAP Build Apps.

 

 

 

Step 3: Setup Integration in SAP Build Apps

Create integration for BTP destination created in last step

 

 

Create API Data Entity with following information:

Name: Specify the entity name (e.g., ‚ÄòOrder History‚Äô for this example)

Path: API Path

Capabilities: List (multiple record) or retrieve (for single record)

 

 

 

The relative path and query can be made dynamic by using a formula, as shown below:

 

 

Next, a Data Variable needs to be created to populate the UI with data based on the integration configured for the entity named ‚ÄòOrder‚Äô:

 

Step 5: Create Build Apps UI

 

In this example, the UI is designed to display only the customer‚Äôs order history. The UI element is bound to the Data Variable created in the previous step.

 

 

 Build and deploy the app:

 

 Step 4: Embed Build Apps UI into SAP Sales Cloud V2

In Sales Cloud V2:

  1. Go to Extensibility ‚Üí Mashups
  2. Create a URL Mashup
  3. Paste Build App deployed URL
  4. Pass context parameters:

https://<build-app-url>?customerId={displayId}

  1. Place the mashup in Account Overview tab

 

Result: True Customer 360 Experience

When the sales user opens a Account overview page:

  • They see unified CDP profile
  •  They can view every cross-channel interaction
  • They know which segments the customer belongs to
  • They get intelligent scores and signals
  • They operate inside Sales Cloud V2 with ZERO backend coding

This turns Sales Cloud into a smart, intelligence-driven selling platform.

 

Summary

By combining:

  • SAP CDP for unified customer intelligence
  • SAP Build Apps for custom UI
  • SAP Sales Cloud V2 mashups for embedding

you deliver a powerful, real-time, 360¬∞ customer view directly into the sales workflow.

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud ERP - Scope Item duplicated in more than 1...
entry.content:
Hello Sandeep,

thank you for your feedback!

The leading columns in this Excel workbook are LOB and Business Area. These attributes are derived from the assignment of scope items to solution capabilities, as defined by the scope item owner.  This is not a 1:1 assignment, which is why you can find multiple rows for certain scope items.

The purpose of this structure is to enable a mapping between scope items and features in What's New and the product assistance on the basis of LOB and Business Area.

Combining LOB and Business Area into a single cell would make filtering impossible, we would lose the mapping.

If LOB and Business Area are not relevant for your use case, you can de-duplicate the records by removing the columns and using the Remove Duplicates function across the work area of the worksheet.

Kind regards
Ralf

entry.title: Re: How to avoid deleting orders
entry.content:
Why your component ‚Äúdisappears‚Äù from the purchase sheets is because of the following:

  • When you add a component to a work order, SAP usually creates a reservation (internal request for stock). A purchase requisition (PR) is only generated if the material is not available in stock and the order is released with the right control key/settings. If the PR is not created, the purchasing team won‚Äôt see anything in their ‚Äúorder sheets.‚Äù
  • If someone posts time (confirmation) before the order is released or before the PR is generated, the system may treat the component as ‚Äúalready consumed‚Äù against the reservation. That makes it look like the requirement has been fulfilled internally, so it doesn‚Äôt show up in purchasing.
  • The purchase department typically runs MRP (Material Requirements Planning) or checks open PRs. If your component is only sitting as a reservation and hasn‚Äôt been converted into a PR, it won‚Äôt appear in their list.
  • In PM orders, whether a component triggers a PR depends on the procurement type in the material master and the order type control key. If the control key is set to ‚Äúreservation only,‚Äù purchasing won‚Äôt see it. If it is set to ‚Äúexternal procurement,‚Äù a PR should be generated automatically once the order is released.

Perform the below steps

  • Check the order status: Make sure the work order is released before expecting the component to flow into purchasing.
  • Verify material master data: Ensure the component has the correct procurement type (e.g., F = external procurement).
  • Look at reservations vs. PRs: Use transaction codes like MB25 (reservations) and ME5A (purchase requisitions) to see where the requirement is sitting.
  • Coordinate with purchasing: They may need to run MRP or convert reservations into PRs manually depending on your setup.
  • Customizing review: You or your SAP team can adjust order type settings so that components always generate PRs when added to work orders.

entry.title: HOW TO DO SAP EWM PACKING REPACKING AND UNPACKING
entry.content:
1. Move stock from one HU to a new HU           
 2. Move stock from one HU to an existing HU          
 3. Move stock from a bin to an HU                 
4. Move stock from an HU to a bin               
 5. Move stock from a bin to a new HU 

 

***  " FOR HU TO existing HU MOVEMENT
  IF p_hu IS NOT INITIAL AND p2dest_h IS NOT INITIAL.
    CALL METHOD lo_packing->get_instance
      IMPORTING
*       es_hu_main  =                  " Structure with GLobal Fields and Indicators in Packing
        eo_instance = lo_packing. " Packing in WM with Immediately Confirmed Transfer Orders

    CALL METHOD lo_packing->init
      EXPORTING
        iv_lgnum = p_whnum "XYZ''     " Warehouse Number/Warehouse Complex
*       is_pack_controle       =                  " Structure with Fields for Packing Control
*       iv_procty              =                  " Warehouse Process Type
*       iv_execute_whr_cleanup = 'X'              " Checkbox
      EXCEPTIONS
        error    = 1                " Error, see log
        OTHERS   = 2.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
* MESSAGE ID SY-MSGID TYPE SY-MSGTY NUMBER SY-MSGNO
*   WITH SY-MSGV1 SY-MSGV2 SY-MSGV3 SY-MSGV4.
    ENDIF.


    CALL FUNCTION '/SCWM/TO_INIT_NEW'
      EXPORTING
        iv_lgnum = p_whnum "XYZ'
*       IO_PROT  =
      .
    SELECT SINGLE guid_hu FROM /scwm/huhdr INTO lv_guid_hu WHERE huident = p_hu AND lgnum = p_whnum.
    SELECT SINGLE lgpla FROM /scwm/aqua INTO lv_lgpla WHERE huident = p_hu AND lgnum = p_whnum.

    CALL METHOD lo_packing->get_hu
      EXPORTING
        iv_huident = p_hu "'00000000000300000039' " Handling Unit Identification
        iv_guid_hu = lv_guid_hu "'000D3A2BB8FF1FE0A6F319AAFCF49C0B' " Unique Internal Identification of a Handling Unit
*       iv_lock    =                  " Single-Character Indicator
*       iv_nlevel  =                  " Single-Character Flag
      IMPORTING
*       et_huident =
        et_huitm   = gt_huitm " Material Items in the HU

        ls_main_data-appl = 'WME'."lc_wme.
        ls_main_data-lgnum = p_whnum."''."mv_lgnum.
        ls_main_data-details = abap_true.
        ls_main_data-lgpla = p2_src_b."''.
        CREATE OBJECT mo_packing_obj.

        CALL METHOD mo_packing_obj->/scwm/if_pack_bas~hu_gt_fill
          EXPORTING
            is_main_data = ls_main_data
            it_guid_hu   = mt_hu
          IMPORTING
            et_huhdr     = DATA(lt_huhdr1) ##NEEDED
            et_ident     = DATA(lt_ident1) ##NEEDED
            et_huitm     = DATA(lt_huitm1) ##NEEDED
          EXCEPTIONS
            error        = 1
            OTHERS       = 2.
        IF sy-subrc = 0.
          /scwm/cl_log=>get_instance( IMPORTING eo_instance = mo_prot ).

          CALL FUNCTION '/SCWM/TO_INIT_NEW'
            EXPORTING
              iv_lgnum = p_whnum
              io_prot  = mo_prot.


          CALL METHOD mo_packing_obj->init
            EXPORTING
              iv_lgnum = p_whnum "''
            EXCEPTIONS
              error    = 1
              OTHERS   = 2.
          IF lv_guid_stock IS INITIAL AND  lv_guid_parent IS INITIAL.
            lv_guid_parent = ls_faqua1-guid_parent." '000D3A2BB8FF1FE0A4C631C0D4825C07' .
            lv_guid_stock  = ls_faqua1-guid_stock." '000D3A2BB8FF1FE0A2B126227A25BC03' .
          ENDIF.
          ls_quantity-quan = lv_fqty."'2'.
          ls_quantity-unit = ls_faqua1-unit. "'L'.

          SELECT SINGLE guid_hu FROM /scwm/huhdr INTO @LV_dguid_hu WHERE huident = @ES_huhdr-huident AND lgnum = @p_whnum.

          CALL METHOD mo_packing_obj->/scwm/if_pack_bas~repack_stock
            EXPORTING
              iv_dest_hu    = lv_dguid_hu "'000D3A2BB8FF1FD0AEE6AB7139E5A000' "ms_hundlernw-guid_hu
              iv_source_hu  = lv_guid_parent
              iv_stock_guid = lv_guid_stock
              is_quantity   = ls_quantity
*             it_serid      = lt_serid
            EXCEPTIONS
              error         = 1
              OTHERS        = 2.
          IF sy-subrc = 0.
            mo_packing_obj->/scwm/if_pack_bas~save(
                        EXPORTING
                          iv_commit = abap_true
                          iv_wait   = abap_true
                        EXCEPTIONS
                          error     = 1                " See Log
                          OTHERS    = 2
                      ).

            IF sy-subrc = 0.

           ENDIF.

entry.title: Re: displaying .msg attachments
entry.content:
If you would like to access .msg files, you can first check the .msg file directly within your Copy & Paste application (e.g., Outlook) via double-clicking it twice; if this doesn't work, there are several websites that offer an ability to view and access .msg files directly from a webpage (also known as "online" viewers) or in your computers native Mail program (e.g., Windows Mail, Mac Mail, etc.). Occasionally there can be an issue with .msg file corruption; in this case you would want to obtain another copy of the .msg file either by downloading it again from the sender or requesting a resend from the original sender.

In instances where .msg attachments are still not displaying properly, the best option would be to utilize a proven third-party product. One such provider is Softaken MSG Converter which allows users to open, view and convert .msg emails directly into other formats such as PDF, EML, MBOX or PST without requiring Outlook. This software provides efficiency and ease of use and is simple enough to be utilized by non-technical users.

entry.title: Re: Unsupported OData Version 4.01 when connecting Fiori...
entry.content:
Hello,

the Sales Order and Sales Order Simulation API using features that are added to the OData protocol with the Version 4.01 and therefore the metadata also define the version as such. The support for this version for was added at a later point in time as the purpose auf these services is not UI primarily. But of cause they can be used for that purpose.

Meanwhile, since Version 1.142 support is added, see What's new . You can get more details here: Transition to OData V4.01 

When you increase the Fiori version accordingly, you are able to resolve this issue.

entry.title: How AI Solutions Can Align with SAP‚Äôs Clean Core Principles
entry.content:
‚ÄúClean core‚Äù and ‚ÄúArtificial Intelligence‚Äù are often discussed in isolation. Clean core is positioned to reduce technical debt and keep SAP S/4HANA upgradeable, while AI is usually associated with new workloads, additional components, and non-SAP technologies such as Python.

This separation leads to a common misconception: that AI solutions, especially those implemented in Python or using external models, are incompatible with a clean core strategy.

In practice, AI and clean core are closely aligned. SAP‚Äôs own definition of an ERP clean core emphasizes standardization, modern extensibility, and the ability to leverage reliable data and AI innovations on top of a stable core. When designed correctly, AI solutions can fully comply with clean core principles and in many cases help to realize the intended benefits of the strategy.

SAP Clean Core Strategy

SAP describes an ERP clean core strategy as a set of guiding principles to keep business critical systems agile, cost-effective, and ready to adopt innovation. Key elements include:

  • Reduction of historically grown complexity and custom code in the core ERP system.
  • Standardization of processes by staying close to SAP best practices.
  • Use of modern extensibility options, particularly side-by-side extensions on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).
  • API- first and event-driven integration, rather than direct database access.
  • Cloud readiness and continuous innovation, including the ability to exploit AI capabilities.

Clean core does not prohibit custom logic or non-ABAP technology. It defines where that logic should run (outside the S/4 core) and how it should integrate (through released, supported interfaces).

Principles Relevant for AI Solutions

For AI initiatives, the following clean core principles are particularly relevant:

  • Decoupled innovation: AI workloads should run outside the S/4HANA core, typically on SAP BTP, and consume data via published APIs or data services.
  • Use of official extensibility models: Extensions should follow the models described in SAP‚Äôs clean core and extensibility guidance, including in-app extensions, developer extensibility (ABAP Cloud), and side-by-side extensions.
  • API-first and event-driven patterns: AI components should use official APIs and events to interact with core applications, rather than relying on direct table access or modifications.
  • Governed data access: Data for AI models should be accessed through governed layers such as SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere, which preserve security, compliance and lineage.

If an AI architecture respects these principles, it is aligned with the clean core strategy, regardless of the programming language or specific AI framework used.

Clean-Core Compliant AI Architecture Patterns

Side-by-Side AI on SAP BTP

SAP‚Äôs ‚ÄúGenerative AI on SAP BTP‚Äù reference architecture explicitly positions SAP BTP as the platform for AI workloads, with S/4HANA and other SAP cloud solutions used as systems of record.

In a side-by-side pattern:

  • SAP S/4HANA
    • Hosts standard business processes and transactional data.
    • Exposes business functionality via released OData/REST APIs and events.
  • SAP BTP (AI and application layer)
    • Runs AI workloads using SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad, where models and pipelines can be implemented in Python or other languages.
    • Uses SAP Generative AI Hub for LLM access, prompt orchestration, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and agentic scenarios.
  • Integration
    • Uses SAP Integration Suite, API Management and/or Event Mesh to connect AI components with S/4HANA through supported interfaces.

 

                       

AI workloads remain in the BTP extension layer, while SAP S/4HANA stays as the clean, standard core accessed via published APIs.

This pattern adheres to clean core because all custom AI logic and orchestration stay outside the S/4HANA core, while S/4HANA is accessed only via documented integration points.

AI Enabled Data Layer with SAP HANA Cloud

SAP has started using the term ‚ÄúAI enabled clean core with SAP HANA Cloud‚Äù, referring to architectures where S/4HANA remains the core ERP and SAP HANA Cloud provides an intelligent data layer for analytics and AI-driven applications.

Key characteristics:

  • Operational data is exposed or replicated from S/4HANA to SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere in a governed way.
  • AI models (classical ML or generative) are trained and executed against this data layer.
  • AI outputs are surfaced in side-by-side applications or written back into S/4HANA via APIs and standard extension points.

The core ERP remains clean and standard. AI driven logic is implemented in the surrounding data and application layers, which aligns with SAP‚Äôs stated goal of ‚Äúincreasing the pace of innovation and leveraging business value through reliable data and AI innovations‚Äù without compromising the core.

Programming Language and Clean Core Compliance

A frequent objection is that AI solutions are implemented in Python or with non-SAP frameworks and therefore cannot be reconciled with clean core.

From SAP‚Äôs standpoint, this is not correct. The clean core strategy focuses on minimizing custom code inside the core and using side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP to build new applications and innovations.

SAP‚Äôs own extensibility guidance explicitly acknowledges BTP side-by-side extensions implemented in ABAP Cloud, Java, Node.js and other languages. AI services developed in Python and deployed on SAP AI Core or container runtimes on BTP fall into exactly the same category.

Clean core compliance therefore depends on:

  • The location of the code (outside S/4HANA vs. in-core modifications).
  • The integration pattern (released APIs and events vs. direct table access).

It does not depend on whether the AI logic is written in ABAP, Python, Java or another language.

 

                                    

AI solutions built on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud surrounding a clean SAP S/4HANA core, with integration strictly via APIs and events.

 

SAP‚Äôs clean core strategy is often misunderstood as a constraint on innovation. It provides the architectural discipline required to adopt AI at scale without compromising the stability and upgradeability of SAP S/4HANA.

By:

  • keeping AI workloads on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud,
  • integrating through released APIs and events, and
  • applying SAP‚Äôs extensibility guidance consistently,

organizations can build advanced AI solutions that are fully aligned with clean core principles. The question is not whether AI is compatible with clean core, but whether AI architectures are designed to follow the same patterns that SAP itself recommends for any modern extension.

SAP AI Core SAP S/4HANA SAP HANA Cloud SAP Business Technology Platform SAP Event Mesh
